Q867: An algorithm is a complicated set of instructions to figure something out. In this case the algorithm would probably take time since last maintenance, how vital the component is to the process, the history of that component (like how long it's lasted in the past), and various other things to calculate when a component will be needing maintenance or replacement.
Q1735: I figure the algorithm can tell when a piece of the machinery is nearing the end of its life, and so Chris is doing preventative maintenance. That's better than waiting until the component fails, which could shut down the production for no telling how long.
Q1737: I figure the individual would rather wait for the part to break rather than doing preventative maintenance, so I imagine Chris would feel frustrated about working on parts that are seemingly ok, even though the algorithm shows that they could be nearing the end of their lives.
Q1739: I think the algorithm is going to take a lot more aspects into consideration than a human would. The algorithm is probably going to monitor how long it's been since the part has been serviced, how much usage the part has had, and the history of that component in the workflow. I also figure that components that are more important will be given more attention so something that is extremely vital to the workflow is going to have the best preventative maintenance to prevent failure, while something that is less vital, but still important, is still going to be monitored but other aspects of the process will be prioritized if need be.
